sections.instructions:
• What is the problem we are trying to solve? 
  • What is the customer pain-point we want to solve? 
  • How prevalent is this problem?
sections.title: Problem
Solution
sections.instructions:
• How do your proposed solutions ease existing pain points? 
  • How does it make the lives of your customers better? 
  • Summarize your product or service in this section.

sections.title: Unique Value Proposition
sections.instructions: • Describe the uniqueness of your product and show its key difference from other alternatives.

sections.title: Unfair Advantage
sections.instructions:
• What is your secret sauce? 
  • What do you have that will ensure that your product or service cannot be copied? 
  • What gives you an edge over the competition?

sections.title: Customers
sections.instructions: • Define your customers, narrow down the customer segment as accurately as possible.

sections.title: Existing Alternatives
sections.instructions: • How are the problems currently being solved?

sections.title: Key Metrics
sections.instructions:
• How will you define success for your startup? 
  • What are the KPIs you want to aim for? 
  • For a service-based start-up, these may be metrics that involve growth and adoption such as engagement, revenue, Customer Acquisition Cost (CAC) and Customer Lifetime Value (CLV).

sections.title: High-Level Concept
sections.instructions:
• The high-level concept sub-section conveys the value proposition in the most succinct manner possible. 
  • List your X for Y analogy. E.g. YouTube = Flickr for videos.

sections.title: Channels
sections.instructions:
• How do you plan to reach your customers? 
  • Which channels will you use to connect with your target market? 
  • Consider the media and channels your key demographic uses, and who they trust: TV news, magazines, social media, influencers or major retailers.

sections.title: Early Adopters
sections.instructions:
• What are the existing alternatives to the problems outlined? 
  • Taking the Uber example further, the founders wouldâ€™ve written down taxis or chauffeurs in this section.

sections.title: Cost Structure
sections.instructions:
• Consider operational costs, both variable and fixed, so you have a clear idea of your runway. 
  • While the numbers only need to be indicative, make sure you do some initial research into manufacturing and distribution costs to give some weight to the numbers.

• Which revenue model will you use? 
  • Depending on your product or service, you may opt for subscriptions, advertising or freemium. 
  • Consider what the lifetime value of your product will be, recurring revenue, customer value and gross margins.
sections.title: Revenue Streams
